This might be confusing because the test functions are not atomic (testing a single use case).

Looking at the existing tests, I noticed this pattern, and I just used it as well (to have consistent testing pattern).

For example, there is `test_resync_pools` that will test all the supported use cases for the `resync-pools` action. That's why there are multiple `actions.resync_pools([])` calls in this `test_resync_pools` function.

The mentioned `bpool` will be used with the use case when the user doesn't explicitly specify the list of pools to rsync (tested a few lines below).

However, the lines added by me are testing when the user specifies a list of pools to rsync (via the new `pools` action parameter), and therefore Juju doesn't default to any list of pools to resync.

manila/tests/share/test_manager.py.message: The intention is to test max_gigabytes here, right? So the number for max_shares should be higher, e.g. (True, 1, 10, 3, 0)
Yes, you're right! Setting the third parameter to 10 makes more sense here

Can you add a note please to sum up, what resources are set up?
I think it is 3 share servers, with 3 share instances and 3 snapshot instances each.
With all being 1 GB this makes a num_instances usage of 3 per share server and a server_instances_size_sum of 6 GB per share server.
With the first parameter being true this adds one additional instance resource, i.e. 4 num_instances and 7 GB server_instances_size_sum to check against. Is this right?

You're correct, carthaca!
So, the first parameter (with_share_instance) is just a parameter to help the test to control some stuff.
The thing is: when the _provide_share_server_for_share method receives a call, a share instance is present in the parameters. This share instance is forwarded to the new method, which filters out the list of available share servers according to wheter the limits for amount of instances and/or gigabytes were reached.
In this case, we must account the new share instance, because it can blow up the limit if for example: the limit of gigabytes is 300, the share server has only 20GB of available space, and the requested share is going to be 30GB size. If we do not check the 'new' share server size accounting the share instance, it could get to 310GB.
But when a share group is being requested and the _provide_share_server_for_share_group method is called, a share instance won't be forwarded to this method, so there is no need to account one more instance, neither it's size, considering that it is going to be a brand new share group.
So the 'with_share_instance' parameter can sound a bit confusing, but its idea here is just to help the test to cover both share and share group creation scenario.
I have added some comments and a note in the test, and I hope it became a bit more clear now.
If you to have any other suggestion on how to improve it or any question, please let me know :)

openstack_auth/forms.py.message:
The commit message says the new setting is optional, but it looks like this changes the default focus, right?
Previously "domain" field was focused but "User Name" field is now fucused by default.

One moree question: Does it work when OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DOMAIN_DROPDOWN is True.
Does autofocusing in ChoiceField work well?

I've tested all the combinations of settings, with or without dropdown, different choice fields, works well on my env. 

The customer's request is about shifting the autofocus to User Name, and I am making is via additional setting since we had a patch shifting the autofocus before. I will rewrite commit message to be more specific, thank you.

I understood the context now. Last time I test the patch, I just opened the login page and did not login.
I think the point is that "last_domain" is populated once a user logs into horizon. In such case, it makes sense to focus on "User Name" by default.

I tried this patch and started to think it looks better to focus on "domain" by default if "domain" field is empty. In the current implementation, once a user log into horizon once the "domain" field is populated by the last domain used (L.91),so it is not useful to focus on "domain" field. I think this is the main motivation of your customer request. On the other hand, it sounds reasonable to me to focus on "domain" field if the "domain" field is empty, i.e., when a user first tries to log into horizon. A user can move the cursor from up to down (i.e., "Domain" -> "User Name" -> "Password").

Considering the aboce, my suggestion is to focus on "User" by default and the only exception is to focus on "Domain" if "last_domain" is empty. If so we no longer need the new setting. Only thing I am not sure is what is better in case of the dropdown.

Thought?

I think it makes sense for the dropdown as well, since it picks the "last_domain" for the initial value too. Also it's the customer's case too.

As we discussed on IRC, your suggestion seems reasonable to me. However I am highly concerned about the autofocus shifting itself. It was shifted from the "User Name" before, now we have a direct request to shift it back. My suggestion is to implement your idea about checking if the "last_domain" is empty but to keep the additional setting just in case it would be convenient for someone else to have autofocus say always on "Domain".

What do you think? And if we agree about the additional setting, should we keep it boolean? Maybe name it "LOGIN_AUTOFOCUS_FIELD" and use "domain", "username" and None?

In the other hand adding the additional setting for an issue that can be solved by pure logic might not be a good idea. We had a discussion about it today. Also another option is to shift "Domain" field to the third place under "User Name" and "Password", and then the focus on the first field "User Name" will be logical and convenient.

I guess this topic is worth adding it to tomorrow's weekly meeting agenda.

I am not a fan of moving the domain field at the bottom. A user belongs to a domain and it sounds tricky to me to place the upper(? I am not sure the right word) concept at the bottom. The order of "domain" -> "user" -> "password" sounds natural to me.

IMHO your proposal of "LOGIN_AUTOFOCUS_FIELD" sounds better to me.

Anyway, let's discuss it in the meeting.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_create_adm.message: I like it but I think this isn't idempotent and we need to add a condition for this to run only if user doesn't exist yet

I tested (locally on both standalone and multinode) the following playbook:

---
- hosts: all
  gather_facts: false
  tasks:
    - name: create user {{ tripleo_admin_user }}
      user:
        name: '{{ tripleo_admin_user }}'
        generate_ssh_key: '{{ tripleo_admin_generate_key }}'
        local: true
  vars:
    tripleo_admin_user: 'ceph-admin'
    tripleo_admin_generate_key: true

with some good results: https://paste.centos.org/view/655c5fd3

In addition, as per doc [1]:

''''
local: true will check /etc/passwd for an existing account before invoking commands. If the local account database exists somewhere other than /etc/passwd, this setting will not work properly.
''''

But a logic != from /etc/passwd doesn't exist in this context.

[1] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/user_module.html

Molecule tests fail [1] because the new task is skipped, so id_user is not available


[1] https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_05d/779358/6/check/tripleo-ansible-centos-8-molecule-tripleo_create_admin/05db7f6/reports.html

Nothing about the ansible user module is idempotent, regardless of if the local paramter is true or false. Thus, the "check if user exists" task on line 18 was introduced to wrap the non-idempotent ask in a conditional. Is there a reason we can't use local true? 

Prior to adding local:true this was failing AND /home/ didn't have a ceph-admin director but /etc/passwd did.
s/shell/command to see the impact on the main job
I thought for command we had to specify binary path /usr/bin/id

Maybe this can be: 

```
when:
  - id_user is not defined or id_user.rc != 0
```
to cover cases where the variable is not register for (unknown) reasons?

[1] https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_05d/779358/6/check/tripleo-ansible-centos-8-molecule-tripleo_create_admin/05db7f6/reports.html

heat/engine/resources/openstack/heat/res.message: Can you elaborate on why _assemble_for_rolling_update() doesn't do what we want here?
IMO _assemble_for_rolling_update got too much extra logic for delete case(like revoke blacklist, sorting replace priority).

Let's not change the template version while deleting the stack, that's a little scary.

Maybe we can define the nested template version as a constant so that we can use it both here and in _assemble_for_rolling_update().
I don't think this is correct - it will *remove* total_capacity resources. I think we want to *leave* total_capacity resources, so there should be no '-' sign here.

We generate template with _assemble_for_rolling_delete and send it to compare with original one. So we take the rest part besides capacity and assemble as a template.

For example with t_c =3 and resources = [r1,r2,r3,r4,r5,r6,r7]
_assemble_for_rolling_delete will assemble template with resources [r1,r2,r3,r4] so the stack will delete [r5,r6,r7] in first batch
Shouldn't we call super().handle_delete() at this point? Currently it looks like we end up with a nested stack containing 0 resources, instead of deleting the nested stack.
It'd be easier to just rename it than to give it two names.
You should be passing max_updates here, not total_capacity.
It's not the total_capacity at all then, we should call it something like max_deletes.

OK, so we're kind of subverting the meaning of all the variables here by getting the batches it would take to reach the current capacity by creating resources starting from 0, when in fact we're doing the opposite...

So in the example from the tests (initial size 10, batch_size 3), we'll end up with the curr_cap, max_upd pairs: (3, 3) (6, 3), (9, 3), (10, 3)

_run_update() ignores the max_upd, so the curr_caps it passes on to _assemble_for_rolling_delete() will be 3, 6, 9, 10. And each time that many resources are removed so the size will go from 10 -> 7 -> 1 -> 0 -> 0.

Obviously we want 10 -> 7 -> 4 -> 1 -> 0.

heat/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: Shouldn't this all be handled in Stack.store()?

The invariant I'd like maintained is root_id should always exist when calling Stack.get_kwargs_for_cloning and if it doesn't exist, then we're the top level stack (where root_id must be stack_id). Then we wouldn't need a fallback on stack_get_root_id().
Yes, that's probably better. Moved to Stack.store().

So when we load a stack from the DB where root_id *doesn't* exist and we're *not* the top level stack, what is going to make sure that it gets populated before Stack.get_kwargs_for_cloning() gets called?

And by "in Stack.store()" I mean it's basically already done by virtue of Stack.store() calling Stack.get_kwargs_for_cloning to get its data, except for the fallback to call stack_get_root_id() when it's missing.

I suppose that might happen if we are updating a legacy stack. FWIW, I'd like to see this patch pass the gates before adding (back) the backfilling for legacy stacks. In the earlier version of the patch, I was backfilling root_id's and the gates passed, but that also meant I was papering over places where I shouldn't have had to backfill in the first place.

I was on the fence about removing this function. My previous patch sets backfill root_id's if this method were called on a legacy nested stack.

But, afaict, this method *wouldn't* get called on a legacy stack. Right now, it is only called when stack resources are created. So, unless there is a corner case I'm missing, I think we can be rid of this function (and its callers from heat.engine.object.Stack and above), and not have to worry about filling in root_id's for legacy stacks.
We can't really, unless there's a Heat manage command to upgrade any stacks that haven't been touched since they were created with the old code.

heat/engine/stack.py.message: I think this should be self._root_id since it may not always contain the valid value, and you have to call self.root_stack_id() to guarantee that you actually have the root stack ID.
I was trying to avoid the db hit in __init__ that such a call would incur (assuming we have a stack_id at least), under the assumption that __init__ should be as lightweight as possible.
If this just called self.root_stack_id() couldn't we get rid of the stuff in sqlalchemy.api?

Counting or getting total resources isn't effected by this patch, since resources already store their stacks's root_id (assuming resources' stack_root_id still gets set correctly all the time with this patch, but I think it should, assuming we always have the owning stack db obj whenever we create a resource).

There is a stack_object.Stack.get_all_by_root_owner_id which is called here http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/heat/tree/heat/engine/service.py#n2213 ,
which potentially could be improved if legacy stacks had their root_id's populated, but doesn't seem worth it IMO (aside, why the parent_id is assumed to be the root_id escapes me in the above link). I don't think it is called anywhere else.

The code in heat.db.sqlalchemy.api was necessary so that resources could populate their root_stack_id column when they are stored: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/heat/tree/heat/engine/resource.py#n1676 . I'm confused by your last question... we are just starting to write to the root_id column in the stack object with this patch. The root_id never should be None after a stack has been store()'ed.
self.root_id should already be set by this point, so I think this is OK.

I guess, assuming something calls total_resources(), but without investigating further I'm not 100% sure that the object we call total_resources() on is the same one we call store() on during a stack update. Wouldn't it just be safer to call root_stack_id() here though and guarantee that every stack gets upgraded to the new, faster way of storing it any time it gets stored in the DB?

Also if we think this is sufficient then I don't understand what the code in heat.db.sqlalchemy.api was for at all. If we always write the root_id to the database how can it ever be None when we get down the the DB API?

> (assuming resources' stack_root_id still gets set correctly all the time with this patch, but I think it should, assuming we always have the owning stack db obj whenever we create a resource).

I think it does here, but not in patch set 4/5.

> The root_id never should be None after a stack has been store()'ed.

In the database or self.root_id here?

My point is that all we need to do is pass:

  'root_id' = self.get_root_id()

to the database and it will automatically get set in *both* places, and we wouldn't need to add any code at all to the DB API to do it, since the root_id we return here gets written to the DB on store().

Yes, but the question is what should get_root_id() be doing assuming we don't already have self._root_id or w/e? I think the options are either going through the db api like in the early version of this patch (which is rock solid btw and also backfills ;-), or recursively loading stack engine objects that keep calling get_root_id() (yikes).
IIUC this misses the case where a new nested stack is created as the child of an existing stack that doesn't already have the root_id set.
Warning seems excessive here given that this is completely expected/inevitable.

I don't get why it should be expected or inevitable. This condition should only happen on nested stacks where no root stack has actually been stored yet, presumably because you want to do something like count total resources in the root stack which apparently doesn't exist yet ... in which case, the caller ought to know better. But it is expected / inevitable right now so I'll switch it to debug().
Hmm, this sucks that we have to do an extra DB write for every root stack, but I guess there's no way to initialise this with its own ID at create time :/
Right, I don't see a way around that. That's the price we are paying db-wise not to have do those annoying iterative parent lookups later.

Harald, can you confirm that this is a safe way to go?
Hmm, I wonder if that is defined later in the process than this runs. When I dumped the 32k vars, net_cidr_map was not defined.

net_cidr_map can actually contain several CIDR's. In a spine-leaf or Edge deployment each network has one or more subnets. See: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/network/network.j2#L276-L300

I think it would make sense to add the net_cidr_map to the global_vars and use it here as well as for the external cidrs above. A THT change with something like this should do it:

Here: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/overcloud.j2.yaml#L1235
 Add a property ``NetCidrMap: {get_attr: [NetCidrMapValue, value]}``

and Here: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/common/deploy-steps.j2#L359
  Add parameter ``NetCidrMap`` in parameter section.
  Add ``net_cidr_map: {get_param: NetCidrMap}`` in RoleConfig -> global_vars in outputs section.
set_facts are really expensive. Can we just do this logic in the template itself rather than in ansible?

So set_fact is a task that has to be evaluated as part of the overall playbook run. Additional task executions are not a 0 impact event.  I'm currently looking into scale related issue with ansible and a single task can add 30+ seconds to the overall execution even if skipped.  Because this is not being used anywhere except the template, it doesn't make sense to have this variable added to the vars being carried forward as part of the overall ansible execution.  I appreciate the best practice and desire to keep the template clean, this logic is not any better when written in ansible task yaml vs a jinja block in a template. In fact it's easier to comprehend when it's actual jinja in the template as opposed to a set_fact.
Unless I'm mistaken, this is just the value from the EndpointMap so should be straightforward.

Depends on the variables. My point was to pull this logic in to the jinja file and process there rather than doing so via a set_fact. A set_fact is a task that has to be evaulated and we need to be cutting down on their use unless there is a really good reason. Since you can do 

{% if tripleo_unbound_name is defined %} in the template file itself and you're not using this value else where, there isn't really a reason to use set_fact in this instance.

Alex, can you provide a cite/reference for the "set_fact" is expensive?
My understanding is this is no more processing here than in the jinja. Didn't any of the slowness with task logic go away in older versions of Ansible?
It does however provide a number of benefits:
1. Easier debugging when the dependent Ansible variables have problems.
2. It keeps the jinja template clean and only focused on the configuration file format required for output. A best practice.
3. It keeps all of the logic in the task so obvious for future developers. A best practice.

I'm interested to learn more about the issue you are referencing.
Actually I'm not sure about this. This is the kind of thing where we would use hiera interpolation I think (e.g."%{hiera('internal_api')}"). What's the equivalent in ansible?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: supernit - Change-Ids > commit SHAs IMHO with gerrit and actually makes this clickable in the review UI.

Would be nice to summarise the reasoning here for reviewers not involved in that discussion. After reading and re-reading the allocation_candidates API reference [1] I assume this is because we want to require HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING in a single provider as opposed to potentially different providers via numbered/named request groups. Is that correct or total gibberish?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/placement/?expanded=list-allocation-candidates-detail#list-allocation-candidates

Not really.
the unnammed group does not require that all traits are provided form a single provded so that is not the reasoning for this.

hyperthreading si a host wide configuration option but in the orginial CPU in placment spec we explictly said that virt driver must not report this trait so that operatos could enable HT on the host but choose if they wanted to report it to placemnt.  the use case here was once numa was in plcment we could enable all the thread on 1 numa node and declare HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING on te numa node RP and then on a second numa node we coudl declare only 1 of the HT siblings in the cpu_dedicated_set so that we could preseve the old isolate cpu thread policy behavior.

we later decided to remove this constriant on the virt driver and have libvirt report HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING

as such this is now a host wide configuration option and it nolonger makes sense to allow it to var per group.
as such we are blocking it in the named_groups which we do not want peopel to use in general and requiring that
if this is set it is only set in the unnamed group.

as i have noted in previous review i think we should be applying the same restrction to all tratis in the HW_CPU namespace and possible all traits in HW though i have not chack all in the hardware namespace. the hardware cpu traits however i dont se a valid usecase for varying in the named groups today and specificly HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/735947/5/nova/api/validation/extra_specs/traits.py#26
Right sorry it's the collective set of resource provides that need to contain the required traits, unlike named groups where it's limited to the same provider right?

this is where we removed the special handeling fo the HT trait allowing virt drivers to report it
https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/commit/4b506d0e9f75200940aa41de419cc626b7dfbbbf#diff-58c3f3699a62919b353e00ffdc5e6c34a955209bfdb3f40234022575e07b0932L166
Shouldn't this be called out in a releasenote given we at least supported numbered groups in code previously even if it was the wrong thing to do?

nova/api/validation/extra_specs/traits.p.message:
Can we use a list comprehension here? Yes, it's slower, but it's arguably more readable.

Alternatively:

  reserved_traits = [
      os_traits.HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING
  ]

  for trait in os_traits.get_traits():
      name = f'trait{{group}}:{trait}'
      parameters = [
          # ...
      ]
      if trait in reserved_traits:
          # These are special cases that are not allowed in named groups
          name = f'trait:{trait}'
          parameters = None

which allows us to expand this list in the future (I bet there are more like this)
Done a bit differently though. Let me know how do you feel about it.
does it actully make sense to extend this to all HW_CPU_* traits?

i still think we might want to extend this to all traits in the the hardware namespace.
but i guess this is an oke start.

certenly traits under the HW_CPU namesapce but im not sure if there are others in the HW namespace that could vary per group and still make sense.
ah yes by removing this match critiria for the restrived traits we block them from being added for new flavors that use the validation.

and when we have numa in placement, we may need to use root_required for this trait. https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/specs/train/implemented/2005575-nested-magic-1.html#root-required

Also, not sure we will support root-required in the flavor or not.

> It doesn't feel like we will use named request group for this.

The old regexp supports numbered groups but does not support named groups. The API validation allows named groups to be present in the flavor extra spec. 

Can I then remove the support for numbered groups then and only allow the unnamed group (e.g. trait:HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING)? Can I raise an exception if a named / numbered group contains the HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING trait instead of the unnamed one?

> Can I then remove the support for numbered groups then and only

 > raise an exception if a named / numbered group contains the
 > HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING trait instead of the unnamed one?

Both of these sound sensible, yes.

neutron/conf/policies/floatingip_port_fo.message: Generic question on this patch, this one keeps old rule in check_str while others I went through dropped it (and had it only in deprecated_rule). Same end result I suppose, but maybe better to have similar changes

I think the ownership check should be happening in SYSTEM_ADMIN_OR_PROJECT_MEMBER, which might negate the need to have a separate OWNER check?

Is a PARENT_OWNER something different from PROJECT_MEMBER?
I just updated this patch to use new rule

Yes, PARENT_OWNER can be something completely different than PROJECT_MEMBER. Such PARENT can be e.g. Network resource and it can be shared with all tenants or with some specific tenant through RBAC API which we have in Neutron.

My understanding was that deprecated rule will be removed at some point but I think that things like RULE_ADMIN_OR_PARENT_OWNER should be kept by us.
Maybe we should introduce only PARENT_OWNER rule, without ADMIN_OR there and add it to the new rule. Wdyt?

Thanks Slawek

I think the old rule (base.RULE_ADMIN_OR_PARENT_OWNER) can be removed since oslo.policy will logically OR the deprecated check string with the new default to make upgrades easier. I'm assuming that's the reason for using base.policy_or here?

Thx. I think I understood it now. I proposed https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/778391 which adds new rules for PARENT_OWNER and NET_OWNER (without ADMIN). I hope I didn't misunderstood You :)

Ok - I think I'm following you now. In that case, maybe isolating the PARENT_OWNER bit into it's own check makes sense because the "admin" functionality should move to system-admin (e.g., SYSTEM_ADMIN).

Traditionally, the RULE_ADMIN check just ensures the user has the 'admin' role on something, but in the future we want that to be the system. I think I'd try to find a way to move the "admin-ness" out of the check into the system-admin persona, then keep the PROJECT_OWNER check separate.

but it will be refstack01.openstack.org only when not running in production (that's when inventory_hostname is set to refstack01.openstack.org) .. anyway, I'm fine with reverting this back to 'refstack.openstack.org' - I put the var there instead when I was stuck while debugging, this makes no difference in production

we usually work around this by either submitting via https and ignoring certificates, or submitting something directly to the docker backend via http and avoiding apache (we have examples of both).

i do think we should return this to just refstack.openstack.org to avoid pointing people at the wrong host in production.

as the last patchsets show, this has to be here because the result submission test contacts the server via http protocol, without this the test will be redirected to the production instance where the anonymous upload is disabled which results in 401 Unauthorized.

this is definitely a workaround, I'm aware of that, but it was the only way I could figure out how to have the '/api/' part in the URL (when submitting data for example).

If I understood the discussion on the meeting correctly, the server was deployed with wsgi before where this setting was present:
WSGIScriptAlias /api /etc/refstack/app.wsgi

Does it mean that before the '/api/' part of the URL was made by a web server magic (a setting outside of refstack scope)? If yes, what do we do now? My only goal is not to change the endpoint - so if there was '/api/' in a URL before, I need to have it there now and the way how is not that relevant, either wsgi setting as before, this workaround or anything else

Any ideas?

The wsgi app seems did the same what 'pecan serve' does now. Before all /api requests were redirected to the wsgi app which executed refstack to handle the request. I would say that the other resources (pages like homepage, about, etc) were served by apache itself - an index.html could have linked the .js files from refstack-ui/app/. Now 'pecan serve' is able to serve everything so no index.html linking .js files is required (just a simple ProxyPass redirection) - which however resulted in a slight change of the URLs.
I don't have access to the refstack.openstack.org to dig even further but this would make sense.
Anyway, I don't have any other solution and I don't have time to rewrite refstack atm, I've already spent much more time on this than I expected. 
I'm gonna make a huge comment in the vhost template so that the weird redirection makes sense to anyone who looks at the config.

Not really sorry.  It does appear that the old site directed /api directly to app.wsgi, but I'm still unclear how it served all the other resources.  in fact i'm not really sure how this new container serves the resources, it seems to run under pecan now?

a priori, it doesn't really seem right to send REST requests for /api/foo to /foo ... at the very least a comment here that explains this would be pretty helpful for the next "lucky" person to look at it ...

Note this will break http -> https redirects when we update DNS to serve at refstack.openstack.org. I think we should leave this alone. You can test things by editing /etc/hosts and putting in an entry for refstack.openstack.org until we update DNS.

> in production it's set to 'refstack.openstack.org', isn't it?

no, it will be refstack01.openstack.org -- we do this to have CNAME's that don't move and the ability to switch out servers underneath, in general.

if this is not here, then the test (test_result_submission) fails - see the previous patch set - because for some reason the request made in the test is via http, which means this redirect redirects it to the real server (if inventory_hostname is not used here) and the real server will make the test fail as it doesn't accept anonymous submissions (plus it's also bad to leave a test make any interaction with the production server and the production DB)
I don't understand how this can break the http->https redirect, the inventory_hostname is used several times in this vhost config and in production it's set to 'refstack.openstack.org', isn't it?

pkg/controllers/bmh.go.message:
In the IPAM idempotency PS (https://review.opendev.org/c/airship/vino/+/778473) it didn't look like the subnet range is taken into account, since an IP pool is associated to a subnet/allocatedTo pair, and we are potentially requesting IPs for multiple subnet/allocated(bmh name) pair here, so won't each subnet get the same IP assigned here then?

could another approach for idempotency be to have the requestor (this function) check ahead of time if a BMH has already been created for a given VM id (presumably can just use the calculated BMH name?), and if so introspect the BMH for existing assigned IPs, and only request any missing ones?
Yeah, I like the slash.  tyvm for the review & brainstorming!

Ah - good catch.  That would only come up if the same host has multiple interfaces on the same subnet, with (different) IPAM ranges defined for each.  At one point I was thinking of adding in the network name onto the end of that, but then forgot why so I didn't.  I think that would solve for this, right -- if you have

1) VMs with two interfaces on the same subnet (but different ranges)
2) one ip allocated to "my-bmh-oam1" for "oam1" network
3) one ip allocated to "my-bmh-oam2" for "oam2" network

That would disambiguate?

Yes I think so. Maybe "my-bmh/oam1" so it's easier to distinguish where the bmh name ends and the interface name begins, and to ensure uniqueness since "/" cannot occur in kubernetes metadata.name (which is a DNS subdomain name)
Oops, thought I took that out!  Yep resolved now

This is fine -- but I just wanted to do a gut check -- is it true we'd prefer to keep this long list of parameters up to date vs saying something like "--query='project=foo, branch=bar'"?  I'm pretty sure the answer is yes (pro: convenient reference for query params in the help text, better syntax errors if the user mistypes, and we don't have to decide on a query language syntax; con: if we add a new parameter in Zuul we have to update this).  But I just wanted to check.

I am fine either way. I think having the help reference for each parameter is much more user-friendly and thus would prefer the current approach. But knowing that the REST API is still "in flux", I'd lean toward the --query argument if we expect filtering and/or build attributes to change significantly.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
So from here why don't we just ensure guest is passed around?

Using CONF.libvirt.virt_type when we have guest everywhere just seems wrong and something someone will eventually have to revert if we ever make this dynamic, some instances using qemu while others use kvm etc.

I was concerned that doing so would make all our other calls dependent on this running first, meaning they couldn't really act independently i.e. by passing them an empty 'vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuest()' instance. It's minor concern but seeing as we use the config option elsewhere (see below), I figured I might as well do the more correct thing here too.

More to the point though, we already have a lot of users of 'CONF.libvirt.virt_type', including some places where the guest isn't in scope currently and might not even make sense:

  $ ag CONF.libvirt.virt_type nova/virt/libvirt/ --no-heading --no-break | wc -l
  76

While I agree that this will need to be changed if we ever want to make 'virt_type' configurable (perhaps by using the 'img_hv_type' image metadata prop), we'd have to fix all of those other uses also. There's likely a whole lot other work needed here too, and the feature itself seems unlikely/low priority so perhaps what I've done is "good enough (TM)"?

Okay fair, I was under the impression that this was always being done first but after looking again I can see that isn't always the case. For now this is fine and others can look into passing it around via guest if we ever make it per instance configurable.

                caps = self._host.get_capabilities()
            self._enable_something(caps)
